title: Part 1
text:
This study is interested in the variables that predict daily productivity [productivity]. The output in each part explores the effect of the following variables:

coffee: Number of cups of coffee consumed
wellbeing: Rating of the wellbeing of each worker, from -10 (awful) to 10 (brilliant)
ai_use: Rating of the frequency of use of AI, from 0 (none at all) to 10 (constant)

Note: All data were generated randomly.

title: Part 1
text:
This study is interested in the variables that predict daily productivity [productivity]. The output in each part explores the effect of the following variables:

coffee: Number of cups of coffee consumed
wellbeing: Rating of the wellbeing of each worker, from -10 (awful) to 10 (brilliant)
ai_use: Rating of the frequency of use of AI, from 0 (none at all) to 10 (constant)

Note: All data were generated randomly.

title: Part 1
text:
Output


Model 1: Productivity predicted by coffee consumption



Call:
lm(formula = productivity ~ coffee, data = lm_df)

Coefficients:
(Intercept)       coffee  
  69.338824     0.009624

title: Part 1
text:
Tasks
Use the output above to answer the following questions.

For every unit increase in coffee consumed, what is the increase in predicted productivity? What can you conclude about the relationship between coffee and productivity based on this information?
What is the equation of the line for this model?
What productivity score does the model predict for someone that consumes 8 cups of coffee a day? Make sure you use bs rounded to 2 decimal places, and round your answer as well.

For the following questions, match up the equation of the line to the corresponding scatterplot.









_____ 1. yi = 20.97 + -1.73xi + ei
_____ 2. yi = 16.69 + 0.24xi + ei
_____ 3. yi = 3.34 + 1.94xi + ei
_____ 4. yi = 9.89 + 1.02xi + ei






Note



Make sure to take note of your answers! You will need them for the Kahoot! at the end of this section.


 
« Back to Home » Next Section »

title: Part 2
text:
This study is interested in the variables that predict daily productivity [productivity]. The output in each part explores the effect of the following variables:

coffee: Number of cups of coffee consumed
wellbeing: Rating of the wellbeing of each worker, from -10 (awful) to 10 (brilliant)
ai_use: Rating of the frequency of use of AI, from 0 (none at all) to 10 (constant)

Note: All data were generated randomly.

title: Part 2
text:
This study is interested in the variables that predict daily productivity [productivity]. The output in each part explores the effect of the following variables:

coffee: Number of cups of coffee consumed
wellbeing: Rating of the wellbeing of each worker, from -10 (awful) to 10 (brilliant)
ai_use: Rating of the frequency of use of AI, from 0 (none at all) to 10 (constant)

Note: All data were generated randomly.

title: Part 2
text:
Output


Model 1: Productivity predicted by coffee consumption



Call:
lm(formula = productivity ~ coffee, data = lm_df)

Residuals:
     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
-23.3091  -4.6321  -0.0388   5.1361  22.6869 

Coefficients:
             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept) 69.338824   0.863736  80.278   <2e-16 ***
coffee       0.009624   0.168431   0.057    0.954    
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 7.352 on 1930 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  1.692e-06, Adjusted R-squared:  -0.0005164 
F-statistic: 0.003265 on 1 and 1930 DF,  p-value: 0.9544




Model 2: Productivity predicted by coffee consumption and wellbeing



Call:
lm(formula = productivity ~ coffee + wellbeing, data = lm_df)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-13.787  -3.302   0.109   3.419  13.714 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept) 65.76981    0.57164 115.054  < 2e-16 ***
coffee      -0.88148    0.11202  -7.869  5.9e-15 ***
wellbeing    2.68643    0.05324  50.456  < 2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 4.829 on 1929 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.5689,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.5685 
F-statistic:  1273 on 2 and 1929 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

title: Part 2
text:
Tasks
Use the output above to answer the following questions.

How much variance in the outcome does each model explain? How much more variance does the second model explain compared to the first? Give your answers as percentages.
Assuming the sampling distribution of b is normal, calculate the confidence intervals for the bs in the second model. How can you interpret these CIs?
Which of these two models, if any, is a significant improvement over the null model? How do you know?

 






Note



Make sure to take note of your answers! You will need them for the Kahoot! at the end of this section.


« Previous Section Next Section »

title: Part 3
text:
This study is interested in the variables that predict daily productivity [productivity]. The output in each part explores the effect of the following variables:

coffee: Number of cups of coffee consumed
wellbeing: Rating of the wellbeing of each worker, from -10 (awful) to 10 (brilliant)
ai_use: Rating of the frequency of use of AI, from 0 (none at all) to 10 (constant)

Note: All data were generated randomly.

title: Part 3
text:
This study is interested in the variables that predict daily productivity [productivity]. The output in each part explores the effect of the following variables:

coffee: Number of cups of coffee consumed
wellbeing: Rating of the wellbeing of each worker, from -10 (awful) to 10 (brilliant)
ai_use: Rating of the frequency of use of AI, from 0 (none at all) to 10 (constant)

Note: All data were generated randomly.

title: Part 3
text:
Output


Model 3: Productivity predicted by coffee consumption, wellbeing, and AI use



Call:
lm(formula = productivity ~ coffee + wellbeing + use_ai, data = lm_df)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-3.5375 -0.6661 -0.0033  0.6941  3.6734 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error  t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept) 99.78646    0.20667  482.830   <2e-16 ***
coffee       0.04617    0.02413    1.913   0.0559 .  
wellbeing    3.01252    0.01138  264.818   <2e-16 ***
use_ai      -4.95959    0.02444 -202.951   <2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 1.021 on 1928 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.9807,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.9807 
F-statistic: 3.27e+04 on 3 and 1928 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16






Model 2 vs Model 3 comparison


Analysis of Variance Table

Model 1: productivity ~ coffee + wellbeing
Model 2: productivity ~ coffee + wellbeing + use_ai
  Res.Df   RSS Df Sum of Sq     F    Pr(>F)    
1   1929 44976                                 
2   1928  2011  1     42965 41189 < 2.2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1






 Standardised Bs


Parameter   | Coefficient |       SE |         95% CI |  t(1928) |      p
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
(Intercept) |    5.11e-16 | 3.16e-03 | [-0.01,  0.01] | 1.62e-13 | > .999
coffee      |    6.24e-03 | 3.26e-03 | [ 0.00,  0.01] |     1.91 | 0.056 
wellbeing   |        0.86 | 3.23e-03 | [ 0.85,  0.86] |   264.82 | < .001
use ai      |       -0.66 | 3.27e-03 | [-0.67, -0.66] |  -202.95 | < .001

title: Part 3
text:
Tasks
Use the output above to answer the following questions.

Which is the better model, the second or third? In other words, is the third model (with three predictors) a significant improvement over the second model (with two predictors)?
Which predictor(s) in the better model are significant and which ones aren’t?
Which predictor in the better model has the biggest impact on the outcome?

title: Welcome!
text:
Welcome to the Analysing Data revision website! This site provides the materials for our revision sessions to help you prepare for the Analysing Data exam.
There are three different sessions in the revision session. They all cover the same content, just in different ways. Your session lead will tell you which of the options you have been allocated to. Select the correct option using the buttons below, or the navigation bar above.



 

Option 1 Option 2 Option 3

text:
